Award.AbstractNarration:
This mathematics research project will support the investigation of several important problems in mathematical analysis. One of these problems is in Fourier analysis and concerns the restrictions of Fourier transforms to curves in Euclidean spaces. The other problems in this project are in geometric measure theory. These fall into two categories. The problems in the first of these two categories are all specific instances of the following: what can be said about the dimension of a set in d-dimensional space if that set is known to be the union of a particular class of sets of a certain type. The most famous of such problems is the so-called Kakeya conjecture that a set containing a unit line segment in each possible direction must have full dimension. These problems lead directly to the study of the boundedness of operators known as Radon transforms. The problems in the second of the two above-mentioned categories have to do with the extent to which certain given patterns can occur in sets of a certain fixed size. A prototypical example here is the unit distance problem. That problem asks about the number of line segments of length one which can be formed by joining pairs of points chosen from a given set.


This mathematics research project in the areas of Fourier analysis and geometric measure theory has the potential to impact a quite diverse collection of science and technology-related disciplines. Here are some examples: Fourier analysis is an important tool in the study of wavelets, and these in turn have applications ranging from data compression and image analysis to communications theory; the study of the restriction theory of Fourier transforms has applications to disciplines that are concerned with waves and wave-like phenomena, such as fluid mechanics and quantum physics; the Radon transforms are the basic mathematical tools which make possible today's sophisticated medical imaging techniques; sets called fractals, which are one of the objects of study in geometric measure theory, provide patterns for the antennae in some cellular telephones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pure mathematics can be roughly divided into the three areas of algebra, analysis, and topology. Among other things, algebraists study questions which originate from basic properties of numbers. Analysis might be said to have its roots in calculus, and topology's roots lie in geometry. The area to which the outcomes of this project belong is geometric measure theory. Geometric measure theory is a subfield of analysis which deals with the sizes of certain sets defined by geometric considerations. Most results in pure mathematics are highly technical and, therefore, difficult to explain without using very technical language. Here we will try to give a reasonably simple explanation of one of the principal lines of investigation pursued during this project. We will then describe, in somewhat less detail, a related problem which was considered during the course of the project.. 

The classical unit distance problem begins with a finite collection of points in a plane. One then considers the collection of all possible pairs of such points. For each such pair, one computes the distance between the two points in that pair. The result of that is a set of distances. The unit distance problem asks "how many of those distances can be equal to one?" or (equivalently) "how many pairs of points can be at unit distance from each other?" The answer will, of course, depend on the number of points in the original finite collection of points. During this project we studied a natural variant of the above-mentioned unit distance problem in which the original set of points is no longer required to be finite. In this case simply counting the number of pairs of points at unit distance no longer makes sense - one needs tools from mathematical analysis (like measure theory and Hausdorff dimension) to describe the size of the colllection of unit-distance pairs. We were successful in employing these tools to obtain the first results on this variant of the classical unit distance problem. 

Related to the unit distance problem is the study of pinned distance sets. Here one again starts with a collection of points. We choose one of these points, call it a base point, and then consider the set of distances from this base point to the other points in the original collection. The resutling set of distances is called a pinned distance set. We obtained results for somethiing called the "spherical averaging operator" (which is actually related to the study of waves) and then applied these results to obtain new information about pinned distance sets.
